TLDR: 90% Satisfactory - 10% Supreme Commander. Good game, not a great game.

YAY! 60 hours into the game and finally get to start building the Dyson Sphere!

The game starts off easily enough to understand. Thing A + Thing B = Thing C, combine that with Thing D and you get Thing E, Thing A + Thing D = Thing.... and so on. If you have played Satisfactory you are going to get the hang of 'Things' quickly, pun intended. The added bit that Dyson Sphere does is add another planet into the mix for certain materials and further tech progression. Up to this point in the game it is fairly straight forward, after about 20-30 hours you should have a decent little economy going with interplanetary logistic routes and the ability to start making mid-level items without effort.

Then you hit the wall. Mid-high level items take so many resources and you need so many of them the majority of the time you are just rebuilding bases and traveling between planets to get an ever more increasing need for more, more and more resources. Oh and did I mention? The resource nodes run out. Meaning you need find new nodes (which isn't hard) and re-route your belts to feed into current infrastructure. At about 50 hours (or at least for me) you finally get to start building the things that the game is named for, the Dyson Sphere. Don't know where to begin? How or what you should build? Don't worry there is a tutorial to help, actually no there isn't. Figure it out yourself. All that time you've spent with the production interface and all those base building skills you've developed over 50 hours. They mean nothing, welcome to an entirely new interface and building strategy. After a session of mucking about with the Dyson Sphere bits I am calling it quits. Is there more game here? Absolutely, I would even imagine it being quite rewarding. I may even come back to it at a later date to finish it, but for now I feel defeated. 

Where the game needs work:

1. The selection system - Needs work. Selecting a building or item requires multiple clicks and deselecting require multiple right clicks. It is sometimes unclear what you are doing. I can't count how many times I went to check how much of an item was in a depot or factory and click on it but only after realize I was in Delete mode and now I have to rebuild it, and its connectors. If the building was to highlight in red when I hover over it it would at least give me a chance to realize my mistake before I make it.

2. Movement - The camera movement is always centered around your Commander. WASD moves you around in 3rd person holding middle mouse button rotates the camera around your Commander. You are always tethered to your Commander to build and he will run into buildings, a lot. When you get flying later on he will fly over buildings making the process easier but always being tethered to your Commander is quite frustrating at times. Imagine playing Supreme Commander and you have to walk your Commander around with WASD and he is always center screen. No panning, no checking another place on the map without you flying the Commander there to look. 

2.5 Movement is 'Cruise Mode' - Essentially fast flying mode. Needs major overhaul. There is no smoothness to this, the controls are atrocious at best. You'll find yourself maxing out your speed to go to a new planet and instead of slowing down and picking a good landing spot you'll just aim for the middle and hit the planet at max speed. You don't take damage and you will not likely be where you want to be on the planet. But that lack of accuracy sure beats the panic induced button mashing, flying inverted, spin-fest that will result if you try making the perfect landing right where you want to. Which undoubtedly result in landing no where near where you intended to land anyway.

3. The skill Tree - Do you like 1000 options of tech trees and skill trees? So do I! Actually I really do and when I saw how massive it was I was in heaven. After about 10 hours of game play I just found myself queuing up whatever I could afford or could make and let it manage itself. No strategy, just keep the queue full with another project. No hard choices on which direction to take the technology or what upgrade I should get for my Commander. I think there is a lot of potential here, just under utilized at the moment.

4. Combat - 10% of the game at best is combat. There is an enemy faction Dark Fog that is also attempting to build a Dyson Sphere and they want the same resources as you on the same planets so naturally you have to fight. Unfortunately they present such an underwhelming threat they can almost be ignored. How do you engage in combat, well, you don't have any ground units so it's air units only and those air units will be destroyed almost instantly in a fight, so don't bother. My approach was to simply build a small line of turrets just of of range from the base the 'almost' never leave and slowly inch closer and closer to wipe out their base. It's not hard and I only need turrets with the most basic ammo. The combat system either needs to present a tougher challenge or removed completely. Eventually I just setup bases with multiple turret batteries and let them come to me, predictably and without force, posing no threat.

5. Dyson Sphere - It's a little disappointing to sink 60 hours into a game to only JUST start building the thing the game is named for. In Satisfactory building the Space Elevator happens so early and with great challenge and then as the game matures you get to see the goal materialize with each new step. It's continuously rewarding, motivational, plot focused and instructional. Dyson Sphere has none of that nuance. I would like to see earlier progression to the main goal. Functional, rational decision making for which next steps to take. Practical learned progression.

What the game does well:

1. Electrical Grid Balance - As I was base building I found myself always aware of my electrical needs. I was never in a position where I was frustrated (unlike the 'coal wall' in Satisfactory) with needs outpacing ability to make more but I still had to plan and account for for an ever increasing demand for electrical power. 

2. Moving Materials - Dyson Sphere has a good set of short, medium, long and interplanetary logistics tools to use. I though the implementation, design and function worked well with the pace of the game. 

3. Base Planning - The game does a good job of making you think about placement of buildings, belts and power as you progress. When you start it is just a matter of getting things to work. Mid-game you begin to think of, how do I make this work better. This is rewarding IMHO.

Overall:
For the price I would, and do recommend Dyson Sphere, it is a good game with the promise of a great game lurking under the surface. I know it is in early access and development is ongoing. I am hoping a little more time for the fruit to ripen on the vine will mature this in to a fantastic experience. For now the wine tastes a little like vinegar.

If you like automation games, this is a must play. You may ask if it's worth spending dozens of hours building a Dyson Sphere around a star?  Ask me again when you've witnessed your Sphere as it emerges over the horizon. If such a majestic sight doesn't bring a tear to your eye, you may be a robot. I also don't like that for a game where placement is so important, you can't move anything; you have to delete and rebuild. While fairly standard for the genre, it makes less sense here.

One of the genius parts of Satisfactory is that they artificially gate you behind "upgrades" in the main story line, which widens and then (importantly) narrows your goals. You are never hit with a billion things all at once, and drip-fed how the game works. This game is the opposite. You get the full tech tree at the beginning and you're only limited by what items you can build - which is in another tree. Cross-coordinating them is a pain, and it's also incredibly overwhelming. I have tried - twice, two years apart - to get into this game, and twice I have failed. I think it's the interface; it just doesn't work with my brain and I feel like I'm often just looking at menus and confused on what to do next. "Being overwhelmed" is the best way to describe playing this game, and it's not in the fun way.

My least favorite part of the game is the conveyor belt, and that's not a good thing since they are such a basic component. I don't like that you can make them backward accidentally, I don't like that they take another item in order to move things into another building. This just makes no sense to me, especially after years of Satisfactory where everything just snaps into place so easily. I also don't like that for a game where placement is so important, you can't move anything; you have to delete and rebuild. While fairly standard for the genre, it makes less sense here.

One of the genius parts of Satisfactory is that they artificially gate you behind "upgrades" in the main story line, which widens and then (importantly) narrows your goals. You are never hit with a billion things all at once, and drip-fed how the game works. This game is the opposite. You get the full tech tree at the beginning and you're only limited by what items you can build - which is in another tree. Cross-coordinating them is a pain, and it's also incredibly overwhelming. There's... kind of a tutorial? A poorly-voiced actor just tells you the next thing to do - which again, just seems so harsh compared to Satisfactory's well-voiced and well-written "AI" character - but even then, it's not intuitive. The parts are also "futuristic" which makes them just seem like random wigits, and I guess they are. It's just hard to care about how many "blue cubes" you're making because it's so abstracted.

I also hate how power works and how my character can't move without using power and I'm sure things get really cool eventually. But I just can't get there. And so I am giving up. And I encourage you, dear reader: give up before you start. Just don't buy it.
